instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message:
Hey I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Motherboard with no power. No water damage but inside was really dusty. I got the following readings

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.61v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = missing

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = missing

<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>= 3.0v

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>= 2.8v

<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = missing

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>= missing

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>= 3.0v

<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>= 3.0v

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = missing


Can you please help me troubleshoot this unit?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message: will i need an oscilloscope for this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message: Okay i tried with the hz setting on my multimeter and got 32.76khz on <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K_PCH</SIGNAL> (<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> pin 10)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message: 12.6 is low for PPBUS seems like an SMC issue. Any corrosion near it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message: no corrosion present. I see the sxhematic says 13.1

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message: Yeah which makes me think the SMC is possibly pulling it down similar to older machines. Inspect near <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> for corrosion as well. I think one or the other could be keeping PPBUS low which explains why many of the voltages you are missing are missing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message: <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is clean but I do see some crud around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. For the newer devices isnt <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> the power ic?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is CPU power supply controller.

Check around <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_PMICLDO</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message:
So would the crud around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> cause anything. its EXTREMELY minor and can only be seen under the scope but there. I went ahead and did a beep test to check short to ground. I have beep on:

CPU_VCCGTSENSE_P

<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_ISUMN</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCSENSE_N</SIGNAL>

Are these suppose to beep due to low resistance or are these lines shorted?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message:
I don't exactly know the corresponding values for your CPU.
But yes, CPU rails have usually very low values...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message: Thank you, so do you have any other suggestions [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message: Check if battery is charging; monitoring <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR> voltage.
